p.s: I'm glad about being the addressee of your sonnet.
When reading that very sonnet I feel very honored!
Especially when you compared myme to time's best jewel.
On top of that, yur imaginary is impressive.
The way you described a summerday in just three words summer's honey breath is fabulous.
Reading those words is like something nature, tasting sweetness and feeling a windy breeze on my holewhole body.
You really know the human soul well.
You have the talend of saying what very one feels and thinks, no matter how paradox it sometimes seems (cf. v. 7).
That's what sets you apart from all the other writers.
Most of them tell stories about their life, their wishes and their thoughts but you, Shakespeare, you are inspired with the talent to write about fundamental things.
Your writing changes withing the time and the exes of the reader.
Your topics are timeles.
I bet, they will be read today, tomorrow nd in the future!
And for sure, they will be read by boys and girld, young men and young women and lastly by people of old age.
Everyone will feel attached by your work and not only me, because you wrote about me, but also others because they can embody themselves into the sonnet.
Above that all, there is no doubt that throughout this special sonnet, my horizon widened extremely.
Reading the lines in which you compare me to swift feet that need a strong hand to be hold back, explains how you felt about our friendship.
Thus, the amount of emotions that are captured in those 113 words is so entiredlyentirely massive that it helps me to empathiseemphasize with others knowing what they are going through.
Short: Your words have a pastoral effect.
May your words shine bright!
